awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Spatiotemporal Organization of Competing Bacterial Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
Bacteria can form diverse community structures, called biofilms  that include special characteristics such as spiral swirls on the surface of laboratory agar as well as in natural environments. Understanding how these microbial structures form is of fundamental importance, as bacteria predominantly function in the form of communities to impact the environment, agriculture, and human health.  Understanding the design principles underlying the multi-scale organization of communities due to competition between members of the community is important, especially as competition is one of the major driving forces that influence how microbial communities organize themselves within a biofilm. An integrated understanding of bacterial competition and its roles in controlling spatial community structure will advance our basic knowledge about microbial ecology and facilitate new developments in the area of  synthetic microbial biology. The research will also provide educational and training opportunities for girls in regional high schools and undergraduate institutions, particularly those underrepresented; simultaneously, it will engage larger research communities and the general public.


Bacterial competition is a major driving force that directs the emergence of diverse spatial community structures. Despite significant advances over decades of research, our understanding and predictive capability for the organization of competing communities remains limited, largely due to the multiscale coupling of the underlying molecular, cellular and ecological events. It is important to determine how the key molecular traits of competition, including its scale, variability and cost, determine the spatiotemporal structures of communities. To achieve this goal, synthetic E. coli consortia will be used as model systems for quantitative exploration; in parallel, a biophysical modeling platform for systematic survey and analysis will be developed. This project will yield a systems-level understanding of bacterial competition and community organization, thus providing critical implications for understanding microbial ecology and engineering artificial communities. More broadly, because of the rich nonlinear dynamics and emergent properties associated with bacterial communities, the planned work will further advance the fundamental knowledge of complex systems in general.

por.por_cntn:
Bacteria often form heterogeneous community structures in space while competing each other for resources. Understanding how their structures emerge through competition is important for us to understand and engineer microbial ecosystem function. The successful execution of this project has resulted in a series of valuable findings and outcomes. On the intellectual side, we elucidated the role of spatial interference scale in governing ecosystem range expansion. For consortia with unidirectional interference, we found the extinction time of toxin-sensitive species at growing fronts is reciprocal to the spatial interference scale. In contrast, for communities with bidirectional interference, their structures diverge into distinct monoculture colonies under different initial conditions, with the corresponding separatrix set by the spatial scale of interference. The findings established spatial interaction scale as a key determinant for range expansion. We also examined the ecological impacts of the variability of interaction strength. For a consortium involving competition and cooperation, we found increasing the variations of cooperation strength drives the community into distinct structures. When competition and cooperation are additionally modulated by pH, ecosystem succession becomes jointly controlled by the variations of both interactions and yields diversified dynamics, demonstrating interaction variability is a key regulator of community dynamics. Additionally, we analyzed the resource cost and fitness benefit of cellular competition. We found that bacteriocin production can contribute positively or negatively to the outcome of species competition, depending on the tradeoff between the benefit of bacteriocins in mediating competition and the fitness cost due to metabolic load. The tradeoff also determines the relative advantage between constitutive toxin production and quorum sensing controlled production. Furthermore, we showed that active cell dispersal is critical in driving competing dynamics. For a community of a toxin producer and a victim, the victim could win the competition for nutrient when it has a stronger swimming ability, even though the victim is inhibited by the toxin secreted by the producer. Collectively, these results provided fundamental insights into microbial organization in space, which benefits the engineering of synthetic ecosystems for applications. Along with the research activities, the project offered a great opportunity for us to train next-generation scientists and engineers, including graduate students, undergraduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and high-school students. It also provided a set of new knowledge and tools to support research for undergraduate iGEM teams. Additionally, the findings of the project were introduced into classroom instruction though the continued development of an undergraduate course. Through the project, we further successfully developed and implemented a synthetic biology teaching module for summer camps specifically designed for high-school students. Collectively, these activities greatly broadened the impacts of the project to a larger community.
